p: Finally, because regional climates are strongly influenced by local geophysical factors such as large-scale orography (changes in air flow due to topographic interference), the pattern of Sphagnum peatland distribution projected for North America may not apply to Sphagnum peatlands in other regions, particularly those in Eurasia. For instance, Broccoli and Manabe [ 67] found that dryness in the continental interior of western North America is enhanced by the climate-modulating effect of the Rocky Mountains. Because excessive moisture is a prerequisite for Sphagnum colonization and peatland establishment, such large-scale topographic influences on regional climate distributions would likely play a vital role in the frequency of establishment and distribution of peatlands.
